title-group.article-title: Differences in Clinical Profile of Individuals With Severe and Markedly Elevated Coronary Artery Calcification Detected by Electron Beam Computed Tomography

article-meta.aff: 1Heart Centre and Department of Public Health and Clinical Medicine, Umea University, Umea, Sweden
2Royal Brompton and Harefield NHS Foundation Trust, London, UK

author-notes.corresp: George Koulaouzidis, Heart Centre and Department of Public Health and Clinical Medicine, Umea University, Umea, Sweden. Email: geokoul@hotmail.com

abstract.p: Although several studies have demonstrated the association between coronary artery calcification (CAC) and coronary artery disease events, the underlying mechanism has not been fully elucidated. Furthermore, extensive CAC still remains a poorly understood phenomenon. The objective of this study is to determine the clinical characteristics and differences between 831 asymptomatic individuals with very high CAC scores (CACS ≥1000) and 497 asymptomatic individuals with CAC scores of 400 to 999. Individuals with CACS ≥1000 were more likely to have hypertension ([HTN]; P = .0004), hypercholesterolemia (P = .0001), diabetes mellitus ([DM] P = .005), and high body mass index ([BMI]; P = .03) compared with individuals with CACS = 400-999. On multivariable analysis, age (P < .0001) and BMI (P = .01) were found to be significant risk factors for the presence of very high CAC. While for males, age (P < .0001), hypercholesterolemia (P = .001), DM (P = .002), and obesity (P = .003) were independent risk factors; in females only HTN (P = .04) was independent risk factor.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The process of atherosclerosis begins early in life and progresses silently until clinical symptoms develop at later stages. 1 Early detection of asymptomatic coronary atherosclerosis remains a desirable but challenging target. Pathologoanatomic studies have demonstrated that coronary calcium quantification can be an effective and reliable marker of the presence of atherosclerotic plaque. 2 –4 Moreover, coronary artery calcification (CAC) is widely accepted as a strong independent risk factor and predictor of coronary artery disease (CAD) events. 5
–9

Despite the well-established association between the extent of CAC and CAD events, the mechanisms of extensive CAC development remain poorly understood. Extensive CAC may represent the end stage of atherosclerosis or may indicate an early defense mechanism against complications of atherosclerosis. 10 –12 The clinical characteristics and the prognostic role between patients with markedly elevated CAC and severe CAC have not been fully evaluated yet. Wayhs et al followed up a cohort of 99 asymptomatic individuals with CACS ≥1000 for a period of 17 ± 11 months and reported that the annual absolute rate for myocardial infarction (MI) or CAD-related death was 25%. 13 In parallel, Budoff et al in a cohort of 25 253 asymptomatic individuals, noted that the 10-year survival was 87.8% in individuals with CACS >1000. 14 Conversely, in a subcohort of the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA), markedly elevated CAC was associated with an increased risk of angina but not CAD death or MI, compared with high CAC. 15

We focused on extensive CAC, where the CACS is >400 and can be as high as 6000. Wayhs et al demonstrated that a CACS >1000 will be useful additional threshold for clinical risk assessment. 13 Until now, little is known about the distinction between individuals with high CAC and very high CAC. The aim of the present study is to investigate possible differences in the clinical profile between individuals with severe (high) CAC, that is, CACS = 400 to 999 and extensive (very high) CAC, that is, CACS ≥1000.

sec.title: Data Collection
sec.p: Between January 2002 and December 2009, 16 247 asymptomatic men and women aged 22 to 89 years underwent electron beam computed tomography (EBCT), as part of a preventive health examination or because of physician referral. Using this database, we selected consecutive individuals with CACS between 400 and 999 and individuals with CACS ≥1000. Demographic information and the presence of risk factors were abstracted from referral letters and questionnaires completed by the patients prior to their test. Individuals with previously documented CAD or chronic kidney disease (CKD) were excluded from the study. Chronic kidney disease was defined as decreased glomerular filtration rate of less than 60 mL/min per 1.73 m2 for 3 or more months.

sec.title: Computed Tomography Scanning
sec.p: All EBCT CAC studies were performed using the same scanner (Imatron C300 Ultrafast computed tomography scanner, GE Healthcare, London, UK) and the same scan protocol. Forty contiguous, 3-mm-thick slices were obtained during a single breath hold, beginning at the lower edge of the carina. The field of view was 26 cm, and the scan time was 100 ms per slice, with synchronized electrocardiographic triggering at 80% of the RR interval. At least 2 adjacent pixels (ie, area ≥0.93 mm2) with a density >130 Hounsfield units were required to define a lesion. The CACS were calculated according to the method proposed by Agatston et al 16 A single investigator reviewed all EBCT studies and confirmed the CACS. Measure of intrareader scoring variability was not considered as necessary; because the latter is negligible with CACS in the range we selected. 17

All patients had given a written consent for the test and for their clinical data to be used for research purposes. The study did not require specific ethics approval since it was based on clinically obtained information.

sec.title: Risk Factors
sec.p: For the purpose of this study, hypertension (HTN) was defined as the use of antihypertensive medication or known but untreated HTN. Dyslipidemia was defined as the use of cholesterol-lowering medications or having known but untreated total serum cholesterol >240 mg/dL (6.2 mmol/L). Diabetes mellitus (DM) was defined as a fasting plasma glucose level of at least 126 mg/dL (7.0 mmol/L), use of hypoglycemic medication or self-reported previous physician diagnosis. The body mass index (BMI) was calculated as the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters. Obesity was defined as BMI ≥30. Family history of CAD was obtained by asking the participants whether any first-degree relative (men <55 years and women <65 years) had had a fatal or nonfatal MI, coronary angioplasty, or coronary artery bypass surgery. Current smokers and those who stopped smoking fewer than 30 days prior to the CT scan were included in the smoking category, whereas the remainder were characterized as nonsmokers.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Results are presented as mean ± standard deviations. Continuous variables were compared using Student t test and categorical variables were compared using Pearson χ 2 test. Associations between risk factors and CAC categories (high = 400-999 and extensive >1000) were examined using logistic regression analysis. In a multivariable model, we entered the CACS and cardiovascular risk factors and computed regression coefficients for CACS and all entered cardiovascular risk factors. All tests were 2 tailed, and a P < .05 was considered significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Of the 16 247 examined individuals, 831 (5.11%) had high CACS and 497 (3.05%) very high CACS. The median CACS for high CAC was 604 (range: 401-997) and the median CACS for very high CACS was 1538 (range: 1001-7908). Table 1 shows the clinical characteristics of the study population. Individuals with very high CACS were older (64.4 vs 61.2, P = .0001) than those with high CACS. Between the 2 cohorts (high CACS vs very high CACS), there were no differences in gender (89.6% males in high CAC vs 90.1% males in very high CACS; P = .85) and racial/ethnic composition (86.4% Caucasians in high CACS vs 90.1% in very high CACS).

caption.p: Clinical Characteristics of Participants With High CAC (400-999) Versus Very High (extensive) CAC (≥1000), Mean, SD, or Prevalence.

fn.p: Abbreviations: CAC, coronary artery calcification; CAD, coronary artery disease; BMI, body mass index; SD, standard deviation.

sec.p: Comparing the clinical profile of patients with very high CAC with that of high CACS differences in the frequency of HTN (48.9% vs 38.86%, P = .0004), hypercholesterolemia (48.1% vs 38.75%, P = .0001), DM (18.3% vs 12.63%, P = .005), and obesity (27.76% vs 21.66%, P = .03) were recorded. More than 2 risk factors were present in 502 (60.4%) of 831 individuals with high CACS and 367 (73.8%) of individuals with very high CACS; P < .001. There were no individuals free of risk factors in both cohorts. On multivariable analysis, age and obesity were independent predictors of very high CACS (Table 2).

caption.p: Multivariable-Adjusted Regression Coefficients Between CAD Risk Factors and High CAC (400-999) Compared With Very High CAC (≥1000).

fn.p: Abbreviations: CAC, coronary artery calcification; CAD, coronary artery disease.

sec.p: Similar results were found when the male subcohort was examined (Table 3); males with very high CACS had significantly higher prevalence of HTN (48.4% vs 37.5%, P = .002), hypercholesterolemia (48.6% vs 39.9%, P = .001), DM (19.2% vs 12.34%, P = .002), and obesity (28.8% vs 21.2%, P = .003) compared with males with simply high CACS. Furthermore, the average age of males with very high CACS was significantly higher than that of males with high CACS (60.8 ± 7.9 vs 64.2 ± 8, P < .0001). Moreover, 79.5% of males with very high CACS had >2 risk factors compared with 70% of males with high CAC. On multivariable analysis, age, obesity, and hypercholesterolemia are independent predictors of very high CACS (Table 4).

caption.p: Clinical Characteristics of Males and Females With High CAC (400-999) Versus Very High (Extensive) CAC (≥1000); Mean, SD, or Prevalence.

fn.p: Abbreviations: CAC, coronary artery calcification; CAD, coronary artery disease; BMI, body mass index; SD, standard deviation.

sec.p: Conversely, these differences were not observed in the female subcohort. Significant difference in the prevalence of hypercholesterolemia (55.1% of females with high CACS vs 38.4% with high CACS; P = .07) and the prevalence of >2 risk factors (65.3% in females with very high CACS vs 51.2% with high CACS; P = .07) were identified. On multivariable analysis, HTN remained independent predictor of very high CACS (Table 4).

caption.p: Multivariable-Adjusted Regression Coefficients Between CAD Risk Factors and High CAC (400-999) Compared With Very High CAC (≥ 1000) in Male and Female Cohorts.

fn.p: Abbreviations: CAC, coronary artery calcification; CAD, coronary artery disease; CI, confidence interval.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our retrospective study provides new information about how gender and risk factors for CAD influence CAC in asymptomatic individuals with CACS > 400 but without CKD or CAD. Very high CAC indicates extensive coronary atherosclerosis and is associated with significant luminal stenosis. Almeda et al reported that CACS ≥1000 is associated with increased age and an increased likelihood of coronary stenosis ≥50% on coronary angiography. 18 Moreover, extensive CAC is likely associated with increased risk of interventional complications and suboptimal coronary stent expansion compared with fibrocellular plaques. 19 –21 Also, trials did not demonstrate any effect of statins on the progression of calcification. 22

Conversely, extensive or very high CAC is associated with more invasive testing and higher costs compared with lower levels of CAC. 23 On the other hand, extensive calcification may play a protective role against complications (eg, aneurysm formation and plaque rupture) or even against acute coronary syndromes. 24 Investigating extensive calcification is still at its early stages and little is known to date about the differences among those with high (CACS = 400-999) and very high CAC (CACS ≥1000).

In the present retrospective study, we showed that individuals with CACS ≥1000 were more likely to have HTN (P = .0004), hypercholesterolemia (P = .0001), DM (P = .005), and high BMI (P = .03) compared with those with simply high CAC (CACS = 400-999). On multivariable analysis, age, BMI, and hypercholesterolemia were found to be independent predictor of very high CAC.

Furthermore, our results demonstrated a gender variation as far as it regards the extensive CAC risk factors. In males, age (P < .0001), hypercholesterolemia (P = .001), and obesity (P = .003) were independent predictor of extensive CAC, while in female subcohort only HTN (P = .04) featured as predictor of CAC.

Coylewright et al 15 studied 257 participants with very high CAC and 420 with high CAC (participant subgroups of MESA) and found that very high CAC compared with high CAC was associated with male gender and older age. In contrast to our results, they did not find any gender variation in risk factors between the 2 groups. This can be explained by the different demographic characteristics between Coylewright’s 15 population and ours, such as the ethnic composition of the studied groups. The majority of our patients were Caucasians, whereas in the MESA study Caucasians were only half of the participants. Also, they reported that CKD was associated with very high CAC; with a greater prevalence of moderate CKD in group of very high CAC compared to group of high CAC. In our study, CKD was one of the exclusion criteria, so the association between CAC and renal disease was not studied.

At least 50% of the 1 000 000 MIs occurring annually represent the first cardiovascular event in people without known history of CAD. 25 Therefore, measuring CAC is a valuable tool in the risk assessment of appropriately selected individuals. In our study, we have shown that asymptomatic individuals, especially older in age men, with more than 2 risk CAD factors may benefit from CAC measurements, while CT coronary angiography would be more appropriate in symptomatic persons. 26 –28

The management of the asymptomatic patient with CAD presents a significant challenge for cardiologists. As the presence of CACS ≥1000 is associated with increased likelihood of stenosis >50% and a very high risk for MI or coronary death, patients with such high scores deserve aggressive medical management and further diagnostic investigation. However, the decision for coronary angiography should not be based only on EBCT findings but additionally on appropriate functional test results.

The present study is the first large study in asymptomatic Caucasians with no known CAD or CKD and very high CAC. Our findings suggested that individuals with very high CAC are more likely to be older, with high BMI. After multivariable analysis, in female cohort only HTN was independent factor while in male cohort age, obesity, and hypercholesterolemia had significant association with very high CAC. The patients are considered exclusively for clinical characteristics, but nothing is known about their outcomes (coronary artery bypass graft and myocardial revascularization). However, providing results about outcome may improve the scientific interest of the article contributing to clarify the role of coronary calcification on CAD.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: This is a retrospective, single-center study. We believe, however, that risk factors were accurately documented by the referring physician or the CT scan supervising physician. The duration of individual risk factors and the treatment details which may have helped to explain some of the differences between the 2 groups were not available. A potential limitation of our study is the fact that the genders are not equally represented in the 2 cohorts, with the majority of the patients being male (89.6% in the group with high CAC and 90.1% in the group with very high CAC). This may be due to the fact that CAC score has been shown to be strongly associated with male gender. 29 –31

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We thank Dr Anastasios Koulaouzidis for his useful comments in manuscript preparation.
